elements.title: Leschenault Lady (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that the Leschenault Lady (pictured), which is believed to be the oldest operational Australian-built steam locomotive, is returning to steam today (22 August) after a lengthy overhaul?

elements.title: American supply in the Siegfried Line campaign (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that due to shortages, American supply in the Siegfried Line campaign made use of thousands of rounds of captured ammunition?

elements.title: Bradley v Commonwealth (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that the Australian case Bradley v Commonwealth held that it was unlawful to unilaterally cut off telephones to a Rhodesian information office?

elements.title: Louis Hempelmann (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that Louis Hempelmann wrote a paper in 1949 that warned of the dangers of shoe stores using fluoroscopes to measure the size of children's feet?

elements.title: Leslie Innes Jacques (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that Royal Engineers officer Leslie Innes Jacques won the Military Cross for constructing a bridge under heavy fire during the Hundred Days Offensive in 1918?

elements.title: vote-a-rama (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that the budget process in the United States Senate often ends in a vote-a-rama?

elements.title: Maki Kaji (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that Maki Kaji formulated the name "Sudoku" while scrambling to get to a horse race?

elements.title: Jessie Weston (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that New Zealand writer Jessie Weston wrote for William Ernest Henley's magazine for 18 months without him knowing she was a woman?
